awd_titl_txt: Molecular Electronic Structure Theory: Methods and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Henry (Fritz) Schaeffer is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Method program in the Division of Chemistry to develop new computational and theoretical approaches for quantum chemistry. This project contributes to the understanding of atoms, molecules, and molecular assemblies in the gas, liquid, and solid phases. These are the elementary components of the chemistry that underlies our understanding of materials from lasers to superconductors and on to biochemical systems. The most important equation in science, the Schrodinger Equation, is the key to new discoveries in science and engineering, areas dedicated to advances of importance to humankind. While one speaks of the Schrodinger Equation, in fact there is a different Schrodinger Equation for every different molecular system. These equations are extremely complicated for systems of broad, general interest. The practical solutions of the Schrodinger Equation require a profound mastery of both mathematics and physics to allow the derivation of important new methods. Dr. Schaefer and his research team excel in the development and application of mathematical physics, algorithm design, and computer science to achieve these goals. An important new method being developed is density cumulant functional theory. The research group also applies these new methods to the solution of important problems in the chemical sciences. Their research on manganese CO2 reduction, palladium catalysts, silicon chemistry, gallium nitride nanotubes, the CF3 substitutes SF5 and PF4, iodine clusters, and atmospheric chemistry, bears upon several areas of technological concern.   

This project focuses on the development of new theoretical and computational methods for the understanding and prediction of chemical phenomena. More specifically, the Schaefer group uses electronic structure theory (quantum chemistry) to innovate, implement, and apply new methods for the description of electron correlation in molecules, one of the most challenging areas of chemical theory. A emphasis of this proposal is the development of multi-reference density cumulant theory (MRDCT). The establishment of MRDCT involves the outline of the new formalism, design of effective algorithms, careful coding of the method, and assessment through benchmarks. Applications of new and existing theoretical methods include molecular architectures; spectroscopy (microwave, infrared, electronic, Raman); potential energy surfaces; energetics; reactions via organometallic catalysts (often involving the earth abundant metal manganese); palladium catalysis for C-H bond activation and reductive elimination; examination of the biologically important class of reactions between persulfides (R1SSR2) and sulfides (R2SR4); and collaborations with experiment toward the synthesis of critically important new main group chemistry targets.  

Broader impacts of the research include the education of a significant number of gifted Ph.D. students (16 in the group currently). Professor Schaefer aggressively and successfully recruits women and underrepresented minorities for their Ph.D. studies. These doctoral students (110 graduated to date, including 23 women) almost uniformly go on to highly fruitful scientific careers in academia, government laboratories, and industry.   Schaefer's research group reaches out to local students in elementary, middle, and high schools.   The Schaefer group is active in the development PSI4, a freely-available, open source, comprehensive, and widely used suite of quantum chemistry computer programs. It is especially easy for scientists   to add new features to the PSI4 code.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: University of Georgia Research Foundation Inc
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA RESEARCH FOUNDATION, INC.

por.por_cntn:
The generous support of the National Science Foundation resulted in a number of publications during the period September 2017 through April 2022.  Among the twelve papers10, 13, 16, 20, 36, 37, 49, 53, 55, 56, 69, 70 describing research on theory and methods, we note here only the recent. Specifically, we highlight the theory/methods research by Adam Abbott on machine learning for the characterization of potential energy surfaces,36 by Boyi Zhang Abbott on new QM/MM methods,37 and by Jonathon Misiewicz on the theoretical foundations of density cumulant theory.53 The comprehensive 2020 Psi4 paper49 leaned heavily on our research group.

Additional very recent theory/methods papers from our group must be noted here, as these required much of our attention. The first, with our student Gustavo Aroeira, on the use of adaptive configuration interaction for externally corrected coupled cluster theory, was recently published in J. Chem. Theory Comput.56 The second, our paper with Jonathon Misiewicz makes important new contributions to density cumulant theory and has been published as well in J. Chem. Theory Comput.53 An additional paper with Jonathon Misiewicz investigates the use of orbital optimized methods with density cumulant methods and has been published in J. Chem. Phys.55 Our research with Gustavo Aroeira and Madeleine Davis69 centers on a new code that exploits the novel Julia programming language for new post-Hartree—Fock methods. This code, named FERMI.JL, can be found on GitHub. The resulting paper describing the program has been submitted to J. Chem. Theory Comput., received very favorable reviews, been revised and resubmitted. Finally, both PIs and our Ph.D. students Alexander Heide and Jonathon Misiewicz are authors on a futuristic paper concerning interoperability among computational chemistry codes. That paper has been reviewed by J. Chem. Phys., and is being revised as we write.71

Our exceptional collaboration with synthetic main group inorganic chemist extraordinaire Gregory H. Robinson bore much fruit,73, 1, 9, 28, 35, 40, 42, 45, 46, 50, 54, 74, 59, 66, 75 yielding papers in JACS, Angewandte, Chem. Comm., Dalton, Organometallics, and Chemistry—A European Journal. Our first JACS research with the Robinson group reported the facile conversion of bis-silylene to cyclic silylene isomers via unexpected C-N and C-H bond cleavages. These compounds represent the first cyclic silylenes containing a silicon-silicon bond. Our first Angewandte research9 (designated a “hot paper”) involved chemistry of a very different nature, namely, the first boron dithiolene radicals. These were synthesized by combining the first structurally characterized (our earlier research) anionic dithiolene radical with the corresponding borane agents at lower temperatures. The first author of our 2020 paper42 on monothiolates was an outstanding undergraduate (now Cal Tech Ph.D. student), Katie Leudecke.

Our research on transition metal systems led to several papers in respected journals. The most influential of these is our review24 on transition metal-transition metal (M-M) bond distances. This paper was published in late 2018 in Chemical Reviews (impact factor 60.6). In 80 journal pages we predict M-M distances for all first-row transition metals, including separately single, double, triple, quadruple, quintuple, and sextuple bonds. Our review includes many risky predictions, some of which may be wrong, but it provides a roadmap for future experimental structural studies. The paper5 with Jonathon Vandezande on manganese CO2 reduction pathways should stand the test of time in the important search for earth abundant catalysts. Our research15 on metal-substate cooperation mechanisms for dehydrogenative amidation catalyzed by PNN-Ru catalysts should also be important for future experimental studies.

Our research group has been fortunate to receive students of very high caliber. During the past four years fourteen graduate students have successfully completed their Ph.D. degrees under the direction of the PI. Of these fourteen students, twelve are U.S. citizens. Current graduate students will be noted later in the proposal. 

Among STEM broader impacts, the NSF-supported studies of the past four years include influential research on CO2 reduction, silicon chemistry, the preparation of fluorinated organic compounds, the anti-cancer drug docetaxel, PNN-ruthenium catalysts, interstellar sulfur chemistry, and H2S— mediated biological processes.


Last Modified: 08/09/2022
Modified by: Henry F Schaefer Iii
